Project Number: 41540-01 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase III
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Regional cooperation and integration (RCI) is a powerful tool to accelerate economic 
growth, reduce poverty, raise living standards, improve productivity, narrow development gaps, 
and strengthen institutions. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) adopted an RCI strategy in 
July 2006,1 and identified RCI as one of its strategic agendas and core operational areas in 
Strategy 2020.2 It will play a key role in helping ADB to achieve its aim of reducing poverty and 
improving the quality of life in Asia and the Pacific. As a result, the Office of Regional Economic 
Integration (OREI) was established in late 2005. To support the implementation of the RCI 
strategy, OREI launched the Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) website in October 2006 
as a one-stop knowledge and information clearinghouse on the progress of RCI initiatives in the 
region.3  
 
2.  This  technical  assistance  (TA)  aims  to  expand  the  creation  and  dissemination  of 
knowledge and information on RCI.4 This will increase the capacity of stakeholders (including 
government officials, researchers, members of international institutions, and other online users) 
to promote greater regional integration. It will help to strengthen ADB's role as a knowledge 
institution by supporting the dissemination of RCI knowledge products. An internet portal such 
as ARIC is an ideal way to disseminate information on RCI. Building on previous TA projects, 
this TA will improve the current content (including databases) of the ARIC website and develop 
new RCI knowledge products.5 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Regional economic integration in Asia and the Pacific has been gaining pace, and ADB 
has been at the forefront of efforts to promote RCI. Intra-regional trade rose from 47% of the 
region's total trade in 1990 to 57% in 2008; while the number of free trade agreements (FTAs) 
grew from 45 at the end of 2000 to 109 at the end of June 2009. Intra-regional foreign direct 
investment inflows (as a percentage of total foreign direct investment for the region) have 
jumped from 10% in 1990 to 52% in 2005. The recent global economic crisis has shown that 
stronger cooperation and integration is needed to maintain macroeconomic stability and sustain 
growth in the region. Other areas of cooperation, such as infrastructure and the environment 
also have the potential to act as catalysts for regional growth.  
 
4.  Under Strategy 2020, one of the four roles undertaken by ADB to promote greater RCI is 
expanding  the  creation  and  dissemination  of  RCI-related  knowledge  and  information  to 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs).  Knowledge  is  a  powerful  catalyst  for  propelling 
development and enhancing its effects. ADB  has country-specific insights through working 
closely with governments on long-term issues and a broader outlook than that of any individual

country. ADB provides knowledge services to DMCs for their immediate information needs, 
while determining and disseminating best practices.  
 
5.  The ARIC website provides stakeholders with access to the latest news, articles, studies, 
and other information on various RCI initiatives in the region. It also contains online databases 
and  information  on  research.  ARIC  is  in  a  unique  position  to  share  RCI  knowledge  and 
information widely, efficiently, and inexpensively. 
 
6.  Maintaining and improving the ARIC website will expand and disseminate knowledge 
and information on RCI to a greater number of stakeholders; boost ADB's role as a knowledge 
institution; and provide policy makers with inputs for research and policy formation on RCI-
related issues. The TA will upgrade existing knowledge products and develop new ones to 
facilitate discussions among stakeholders, and to enhance their capacity to promote greater 
regional integration. In addition, a separate OREI intranet site will be developed to serve as a 
venue for RCI information sharing within ADB. The information available in the intranet site will 
be used by ADB staff in evaluating and designing RCI  projects. This will increase ADB's 
knowledge  pool  on  RCI  projects  and  set  the  pace  for  ADB-wide  information  sharing, 
strengthening OREI's role as the focal point in supporting RCI initiatives in Asia. 
 
7.  The ARIC website traces its roots to the Asia Recovery Information Center website 
developed by ADB in 1999. This provided a clearinghouse for the dissemination and exchange 
of information on the economies hit by the Asian crisis 1997–1998 and on their recovery. Since 
its re-launch as the Asia Regional Integration Center in October 2006, the ARIC website has 
established itself as a reliable and leading source of RCI information. On average, there are 
around 655 unique visitors and 23,920 hits per day. The website’s information architecture, 
database systems, and state-of-the-art technology have been used as benchmarks by other 
institutions. ARIC has been consulted by the Secretariat for the Common Market for Eastern 
and Southern Africa with regard to its plan to establish a regional integration surveillance 
mechanism. The ARIC website was also included by the Center for Comparative Regional 
Integration Studies at United Nations University in its best-practice analysis of online resources 
dealing with integration studies. The ARIC project team assisted the Association of Southeast 
Asian  Nations  Secretariat  in  developing  the  sections  covering  statistics  and  economic 
integration in its website. ARIC’s FTA section is currently linked to the Asia-Pacific trade and 
investment agreements database, which is maintained by the United Nations Economic and 
Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific.  
 
8.  The ARIC project team helped create RCI knowledge products, including 35 working 
papers on regional economic integration; 33 presentation materials from RCI seminar series; 
17 issues of the Asia Economic Monitor (AEM);6 an FTA comparative toolkit; updated RCI 
indicators; an expanded macroeconomic database; and a climate change database. AEM is an 
established brand name covered widely by the international media (with major international 
newspapers often carrying front-page articles based on AEM stories), and highly appreciated by 
users (as evidenced by 90,000 downloads in 2009). 
 
9.  Several  lessons  have  been  learned  from  the  implementation  of  previous  ARIC  TA 
projects. First, an important element in the development of the website is the feedback it 
receives  from  internal  and  external  stakeholders,  which  have  significantly  improved  and 
streamlined its content and structure. Second, ARIC must improve continuously to fulfill its 
mandate of becoming an authoritative source of information on RCI in Asia and the Pacific. 
                                                 
6  ADB, Asia Regional Integration Center. Asia Economic Monitor. http://aric.adb.org/asia-economic-monitor/

3
Third, to attract more users, the ARIC website should increase the consistency and originality of 
its content, and conform to ADB standards in information presentation. Fourth, while enhancing 
its strengths (the money and finance content), it should also emphasize other RCI pillars: cross-
border infrastructure, trade and investments, and other regional public goods. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA aims to enhance the capacity of key stakeholders to promote greater regional 
integration by expanding the creation and dissemination of knowledge and information on RCI. 
The impact of the TA will be reflected in the number and scope of market-led and government-
directed RCI initiatives, intra-regional agreements and other venues for cooperation, and the 
implementation of existing RCI activities in Asia and the Pacific and the development of new 
initiatives. 
 
11.  The outcome of this TA will be that stakeholders will have access to timely and relevant 
knowledge and information on RCI, including the latest RCI news and information, regional 
integration  and  macroeconomic  indicators,  and  RCI  knowledge  products,  including  books, 
reports,  working  papers,  a  digest  of  RCI  activities,  and  country  profiles.  They  could  also 
participate in strategic discussions on the impact and policy implications of RCI through regional 
economic integration seminars. It is anticipated that the TA will increase usage of the website by 
10% (compared to the average from the date of ARIC's re-launch to December 2009). Its 
outcome can also be measured by the amount of time spent on a website and the number of 
downloads, and by the number of direct links from various global and regional websites.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will revamp the existing website to include expanded and new content and will 
introduce more tools for improved user web experience and accessibility. The tasks will include 
(i) revamping  and  enhancing  the  ARIC  website  and  launching  a  new  OREI  intranet  site; 
(ii) preparing  the  AEM  and  other  new  economic  reports,  and  updating  current  databases; 
(iii) developing  new  knowledge  products  and  databases;  (iv)  providing  assistance  in  the 
preparation of the ADB working paper series on regional economic integration; (v) providing 
support for the OREI seminar series; and (vi) undertaking other initiatives that will help increase 
web usage and direct links with other relevant websites. The TA will cover all ADB DMCs. 
Assistance will not be undertaken in any DMC until ADB receives a notice of no-objection from 
the government of the DMC. 
 
13.  The  website’s  navigational  structure  will  be  overhauled  to  provide  visitors  with  a 
substantially  improved  user  experience. Knowledge  tools  will  be  presented  using  geodata, 
dashboards, multimedia, and dynamic data presentation to help widen statistical analysis. The 
TA will develop a new OREI intranet site in collaboration with internal ADB stakeholders. The 
intranet site will promote the harmonization and synchronization of data within ADB. In addition, 
the intranet site will serve as an information focal point for the ADB internal community of 
practice on RCI and help strengthen ARIC’s efforts to support internal users. 
 
14.  The TA will maintain and update the ARIC's existing content and develop new content. 
New  issues  of  AEM  will  be  published  and  the  current  content  and  databases  on  trade, 
investment,  and  macroeconomic  indicators  will  be  updated  and  expanded  to  include  new 
initiatives, coverage, and indicators. The TA will develop new databases on infrastructure,

4   
bilateral investment treaties, tariffs, energy resources, and the Asian Highway.7 New knowledge 
products on RCI will also be developed—including a digest (which will provide updates on the 
progress and status of various initiatives under each of the four pillars of RCI8), and country 
profiles (which will provide country information on RCI-related topics). The TA will involve other 
departments in ADB in developing new content on the ARIC website, which will complement 
other initiatives being implemented within ADB. OREI may also work with regional departments 
of ADB to link documents in languages other than English to the ARIC website. 
 
15.  To disseminate new knowledge and information on RCI, five to seven seminars will be 
held during TA implementation. Eight to ten working papers focusing on various issues related 
to the four pillars of RCI will be produced and disseminated. Experts on RCI will be invited to 
contribute to the seminars and the working paper series.  
 
16.  Promoting and marketing the ARIC website will be important to achieving the outcome of 
the TA. Key stakeholders must be aware of the website and the information it contains. OREI 
will coordinate with internal and external stakeholders to encourage links between the ARIC 
website and other sites. The ARIC website will include survey tools so users can provide 
feedback, enabling the website to be tailored more closely to user needs. Networking services 
(such as Twitter and RSS [Really Simple Syndication]) will be used and user participation and 
discussion on various RCI issues encouraged. The TA will explore ways of enhancing general 
accessibility  to  the  website's  knowledge  products  of  the  placement  of  links  at  multilingual 
development portals, as well as through the inclusion of a technical glossary.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA will require an estimated $1,250,000 to be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV  for  $400,000  and  TASF—other  sources  for 
$850,000). The detailed cost breakdown and financing plan are detailed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. OREI will implement the TA in close 
collaboration with other ADB departments and offices. The community of practice on regional 
cooperation and integration will provide advice and guidance as required. The TA is expected to 
be completed in 24 months, from December 2009 to November 2011 
 
19.  The TA will require 34 person-months of international consulting services, 226 person-
months  of  national  consulting  services,  and  approximately  0.6  person-months  of  resource 
persons' services (Appendix 3, Table A3). All of the consultants will be hired as individuals and 
in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  Outline  terms  of  reference for  the  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  Hiring  a  team  of 
individual consultants will provide more benefits to ADB than engaging a firm. These include  
(i) faster mobilization of consultants, (ii) greater control by ADB staff in selecting and managing 
individual consultants, and (iii) greater flexibility in engaging experts specializing in a broad 
range of RCI-related topics.  
                                                 
7 The Asian Highway is a system of about 140,000 kilometers of roads crisscrossing many Asian countries and with 
linkages to Europe. Under another OREI TA, a database was developed on ADB-financed road projects that 
contributed to the Asian Highway network.This database will be uploaded in the ARIC website and be made 
available to ADB staff and key stakeholders as inputs to the design and evaluation of future regional road projects. 
8 The four pillars of ADB's RCI Strategy are: (i) cross-border infrastructure and related software, (ii) trade and 
investment, (iii) money and finance, and (iv) regional public goods.

20.  The lead economist, with expertise in trade, macroeconomic, or development issues in 
Asia, will be an international consultant and will supervise the revamp of the website and the 
day-to-day operations of the ARIC. Other international consultants will include six economists 
familiar  with  RCI  issues  in  Asia  who  will  prepare  special  studies  with  significant  policy 
implications for RCI and one economics editor who will draft the contents of the ARIC website 
and edit the AEM and working papers. About six resource persons, who are internationally 
distinguished experts on RCI or policy makers considered as prime movers of Asian integration 
will be invited as speakers for OREI seminars.  
 
21.  National consultants will include one lead analyst who will assist in the supervision of 
ARIC’s  operations;  seven  economic  analysts  who  will  maintain  and  improve  the  website’s 
content, and assist in the preparation of publications and seminars; and one analyst on trade 
law who will operate and improve the trade- and investment-related sections of the ARIC 
website. Three web and/or IT specialists will be hired as a website administrator, a multimedia 
designer and developer, and system and/or database developer. There will also be one desktop 
publisher  for  the  AEM  reports;  and  one  project  management  assistant  who  will  provide 
administrative, logistical and data support. To successfully implement this TA, a team of OREI 
staff  including  one  professional  member  of  staff,  one  national  officer,  and  one  operations 
assistant, assisted by the lead economist, lead analyst and project management assistant, will 
consolidate consultants' individual outputs as well as coordinate and manage consultants. 
 
22.  The  procurement  of  equipment,  software,  and  statistical  databases  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). After the 
TA is completed, any procured equipment will be disposed of in compliance with ADB project 
administration instructions on administering grant-financed technical assistance projects.9 
 
23.  The  improved  ARIC  website  will  be  promoted  through  events  sponsored  by  key 
stakeholders.  Printed copies of the AEM and OREI working papers, and ARIC brochures and 
other marketing paraphernalia will be distributed during these promotional events. News on the 
launch of the new ARIC website and issuance of the semiannual AEM reports will also be 
released  to  the  media.  Seminars  and  workshops  on  regional  economic  integration  will  be 
conducted  to  disseminate  the  TA’s  expected  knowledge  products.  The  project  monitoring 
framework will be improved and used to assess the impact and outcome of the TA. The TA will 
be monitored through monthly ARIC website user statistics as well as through midterm and final 
TA review reports. RCI news, comments, and suggestions from key stakeholders and ADB staff 
will also be tracked. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,250,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase III, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Lead Economist (18 person-months) 
1.  The consultant will be an economist with expertise in trade, macroeconomic, and development 
issues in Asia and the Pacific, with at least 10 years of relevant work experience. Under the supervision 
of Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff, the lead economist will  
(i)  manage  the  improvement,  expansion,  and  daily  operations  of  the  Asia  Regional 
Integration Center (ARIC) website; 
(ii)  evaluate  and  improve  the  content  and  operational  procedures  of  the  ARIC  website, 
including the ARIC work plan; 
(iii)  develop and implement a monitoring framework for the ARIC website; 
(iv)  assist in the preparation of regular macroeconomic and financial reports; 
(v)  provide research inputs as may be requested by ADB staff; 
(vi)  manage the production of ADB working paper series on RCI and oversee preparations for 
the ADB seminar series on regional cooperation and development (RCI); and 
(vii)  liaise with various ADB departments and offices. 
 
2.  Outputs will include regular reports on overall activities of ARIC team and performance of or 
improvements on the ARIC website, written inputs and/or comments on logic and substance in support of 
preparation of various RCI knowledge products.  
 
2.  Economists (6 persons, 6 person-months total, intermittent) 
3.  The consultants will be economists familiar with trade, macroeconomic, and development issues 
in Asia and the Pacific. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultants will  
(i)  prepare special studies on agreed RCI-related topics; and 
(ii)  revise and finalize the study based on comments from OREI and other departments. 
 
4.  Outputs will include written reports and presentations on special studies regarding RCI issues. 
 
3.  Economics Editor (10 person-months, intermittent) 
5.  The consultant should be familiar with economic and development issues in Asia and the Pacific, 
and have strong communication skills. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant will  
(i)  draft contents of the ARIC website, the Asia Economic Monitor (AEM), ADB working 
papers on regional economic integration, management statements, press releases, and 
technical documents; 
(ii)  examine economic arguments in documents to assess whether they are logical and are 
based on accepted economic theory and principles, and revise them if necessary; 
(iii)  examine and edit the tables and figures in the documents to ensure data consistency; and 
(iv)  ensure that documents adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high publication 
standards. 
 
6.  Outputs will include edited content of ARIC website, management statements, press releases, 
OREI  publications  and  technical  documents;  and  written  notices  to  OREI  paper  authors  regarding 
comments on substance and logic of arguments and adherence to ADB style and usage.

Appendix 3  11
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Lead Analyst (18 person-months) 
7.  The consultant will have sufficient managerial skills to perform supervisory tasks; knowledge of 
economic issues; website and database management and development; and strong proficiency in data 
processing and analysis. The local consultant will 
(i)  perform the tasks of the lead economist in his or her absence; 
(ii)  assist in the supervision of the daily operations of the ARIC website;  
(iii)  support the lead economist in preparing management reports related to ARIC; 
(iv)  liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ARIC-related matters; 
(v)  develop and maintain systems for data aggregation and computation; 
(vi)  provide research support in the preparation of various RCI knowledge products; and 
(vii)  execute data and research requests. 
 
8.  Outputs will include regular reports on overall activities of ARIC team and performance of the 
ARIC website, reports on improvements to the ARIC website, occasional updates on services rendered 
in support of OREI and related ADB activities, written inputs and/or comments on logic and substance in 
support of preparation of various RCI knowledge products.  
 
2.  Economic Analysts (7 persons, 126 person-months total) 
9.  The consultants will have extensive experience in economic, social, and financial data processing 
and analysis; be familiar with issues concerning RCI; and have strong communication skills. Under the 
supervision of ADB staff and the ARIC lead economist, the consultants will 
(i)  maintain and develop the following sections of the website: (a) infrastructure and software; 
(b) trade and investment; (c) money and finance; (d) regional public goods; (e) the RCI 
indicators  database;  (f)  integration  indicators  database;  (g)  economic  and  financial 
indicators; (h) Asian macroeconomic development section; and (i) other sections of the 
ARIC website as may be assigned; 
(ii)  assist in conceptualizing website design;  
(iii)  develop and update RCI knowledge products, including (a) an RCI digest; and (b) country 
profiles on RCI for assigned countries;  
(iv)  provide research and editorial assistance in the preparation of regular economic and 
financial reports, working papers, and other material; and 
(v)  provide coordination support for OREI seminar series and website promotion. 
 
10.  Outputs will include written portions of RCI knowledge products and website content, written 
economic updates and analysis and reports, updated economic and financial databases, and reports on 
website improvements.  
 
3.  Analyst—Trade Law (6 person-months) 
11.  The consultant will have a university degree in law with several years of relevant experience in 
providing economic and legal analysis of international agreements, particularly free trade agreements 
(FTAs) and bilateral investment treaties; good report-writing skills; substantial knowledge of international 
trade, FTA trends, and best practices. Familiarity with FTA and foreign direct investment regimes of 
Asian economies and developed countries is desirable. Under the supervision of the ADB staff and ARIC 
lead economist, the consultant will 
(i)  assist in analyzing recent trends in Asian FTAs and investment agreements; 
(ii)  manage and maintain the ARIC FTA database;

Appendix 3  13
 
18.  Outputs  will  include  (i)  design  of  a  user  evaluation  framework  for  the  site  and  technical 
documentation,  (ii) system  requirements  specifications  for  the  website  and  documentation,  
(iii) preparation of a user and/or operations manual for the ARIC system, and (iv) maintenance and 
development of ARIC databases. 
 
7.  Desktop Publisher (1–2 persons, 4 person-months total) 
 
19.  In consultation with and under the guidance of ADB staff, the consultant will  
(i)  lay out and incorporate revisions to the text, tables, and charts of the AEM; and 
(ii)  convert the files into required format for print and online publication. 
 
20.  Outputs will include typesetting of AEM and other relevant ARIC publications. 
 
8.  Project Management Assistant (18 person-months) 
21.  Under the supervision of the ARIC lead economist, the consultant will 
(i)  assist  the  team  members  with  all  the  logistical  arrangements  and  manage  all 
administrative procedures; 
(ii)  organize files comprising reports, computer files and other relevant documents; 
(iii)  assist in maintaining online databases and data collection; 
(iv)  construct and organize the monthly economic calendar; 
(v)  monitor and prepare reports on ARIC procedures; 
(vi)  serve as the supply custodian of the team; and 
(vii)  assist in proofreading, editing and reformatting of the ADB working paper series on RCI. 
 
22.  Outputs will include drafts of various documents and reports necessary for TA implementation.  
 
C.  Resource Persons (6 persons, 0.6 person-month total, intermittent) 
23.  These  consultants  will  be  internationally  distinguished  experts  on  the  four  pillars  of  RCI, 
specializing in RCI issues, or policy makers who are considered prime movers of Asian integration. The 
resource persons will 
(i)  make presentations on topics assigned to them; and  
(ii)  act as moderators and facilitators.  
 
24.  Outputs will include presentations on assigned topics.
